intro: Puya woronowii, commonly known as the Andean torch, is a striking plant native to the high Andes of South America. It is a member of the Bromeliaceae family and is characterized by its tall, spiky inflorescence that can reach heights of up to 10 meters. The plant produces vibrant red or orange flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as hummingbirds and bees. Its leaves form a rosette that collects rainwater, providing a habitat for small organisms. Puya woronowii is adapted to harsh alpine conditions and is often found growing in rocky, well-drained soils.
